author: {'steamid': '76561197992276385', 'num_games_owned': 235, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 5290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1044, 'playtime_at_review': 4773, 'last_played': 1712480391}
review:
I really like this game a lot. Even though it's not really a Tycoon.

It's basically design your own little MMO. It is lacking in a lot of desirable features at this point.
The game progresses by adding things to the world. whether it's a bush or a chapel, you get the same progress points. regardless of size or cost. These points unlock some (not all made yet) features of the game and mostly just add bonuses to the player types who may buy the game.

You can build neat area's and kind of set up cool quest lines. But it's either kill this or go here. More of a way to lead your players to certain area's.

Multi-select being added is huge. being able to group object into one object is huge. copy and pasting that cluster and not getting update progress is not cool.

Multi select needs to offer a way for you to also edit NPC's - example I made a dungeon where I threw in about 400 NPC. it's supposed to be a grind on weak 1hp monsters. Problem is they award the same amount of EXP. I noticed this after I placed 400. I'm not individually changing 400 units. I ended up reworking how much exp it takes to level from killing. People are still jumping from level 5-7/8 halfway through the dungeons. The same Idea goes for shops. Especially if I want to increase prices per region. Maybe the sync can be Global vs Region.

I'm looking forward to eventual guilds, factions, and all that entails, but PLEASE CONSIDER THIS AS A PRIORITY.

Equipment. This doesn't have to be animated at the start, but my god is the game missing huge potential here that would make it more than a "oh I made a pretty place" sim.

You should be able to make equipment that has stats + a level + a cost. These can be icons like abilities right now. These would give players nice buffs which would really help with bosses as well.

You should select shops and allow it to sell through X level range. Then select the items you want it to sell that you've made. Say it's a level 10 area and I want to provide basic level 10 equipment in town. But I want a masterwork smith to be in the mountains, so they have to travel to a shop out there to get that specific equipment.

I think this would be huge and add a lot to gold spend. especially if you can adjust prices. Adding dungeons and not understanding the economic impact of loot before launching has thrown my games economies into a whack.

I have a ton of players who have 2-4k in gold.
Then I have a bunch around 500. My only way to equalize it is to punish new players by making everything cost 50-500 gold. and a bit for transport too.


overall I do love this charming game. can't wait for future updates,

author: {'steamid': '76561198000344896', 'num_games_owned': 607, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 1106, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1106, 'last_played': 1684355034}
review:
As of today, 3/5/2024, they finally released a roadmap for the game, their plans before full release. It took four years for them to do this. Their first promised feature and first complete node on said roadmap, the dungeons update, also took four years to finish, and came less than a month ago in a yet-to-be-polished state.

To be fair to the developers, four years ago was 2020, the dreaded year that never was, and very few things remained on schedule, period. But, if you're buying this game expecting it to be finished some time before 2040, I'd maybe hold off. The next node on their roadmap, which the devs haven't even started on, is a proper progression system for the game, with tech/feature unlocks and goals. So, if you want there to be something to _do_ in your video game, something to work towards, check back in 2028.

Currently how the game works is you have a version number in the upper corner of your screen, which increases by .001 every time you buy something, anything. Every asset you add to your virtual world costs money for some reason, even if it's the same asset copy/pasted. every hundred bits you buy and add to your game lets you stop and unlock something, though, most of these unlocks add some invisible % to your income or have a big WORK IN PROGRESS plastered over them, and others represent things that probably shouldn't be unlockables, like the ability for players to have friends lists? Each map zone is way, way too large for the amount of content you have to fill it with, so much of the game right now revolves around spamming tiny scenery bobs to clear out that tech tree of the upgrades that do anything, and then sitting back and letting the game run. Every time one of your players reaches a new level, it's time to pause the game, buy a new map zone for that level, and fill it with bits and bobs again, until eventually players hit a level cap and there's nothing left to do but watch your little sea monkey aquarium.

If you noticed I've said nothing substantial about the mmo itself, that's because there's nothing substantial _about_ the mmos themselves. Importantly, there's very little of an economy in your business tycoon game, especially if you want to go the f2p route. None of the standard ways mmo devs nickel and dime customers are present in this business simulation game. No character slots, no premium subs or trial periods, no gold sink gear upgrades with a failure chance, no xp boosts, no mounts, no cosmetics, no gacha. Not that any of us are fans of such systems, but, in a game about being the people in charge squeezing money out of players, you'd think there would be ways to squeeze money out of players. Your virtual players don't have much of an economy either, which is a whole different rant on missed opportunities.

Basically, if the idea of this game excites you because mmos revolve around their virtual economies and this is a perfect backdrop for a tycoon game, you'll be disappointed with the current state of the game. You'll probably be disappointed with the finished game, too, if it ever does finish, because there isn't a single mention of the economics or business side anywhere in the roadmap. It is, in order, the progression system, pvp factions, raids, a help menu?, weather events, twitch and workshop integration. That's it for feature updates. It's pretty clear the development focus is on making specific styles of mmo world, with all the business and management stuff as an afterthought.

review:
The game is really enjoyable so far, at least for an early access game. 
It gives a few hours of fun content, the balancing is a bit off sometimes and I wished there was some kind of help tool that helps you balance monsters and classes a bit until you get a feel for the game.

After a few hours it turns a bit empty though, the gameplay loops becomes a bit repetetive as of now, new biome, new enemies you need to create, balance and place, and then decorating everyting. The dungeons seem like they have a lot of potential but there's not enough yet to make an entire playthrough fun enough. My players only got to level 4 with a select few reaching 5 / 6 so there's a lot of time to fill with content yet.

I also wished there was some kind of ingame economy, crafting or job system to design for players. Mircomanage equipment, and its values and balancing and let players trade it. Preferably only as an optional thing though.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995164965', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 4818, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4748, 'last_played': 1709852052}
review:
I really enjoy this game. Whenever I get the inspiration to make something, but know trying to make something so big will end with me overwhelmed, I pick up this game again. It has some boxes to add lore to towns and zones, so I can feel like I'm building my own world.

As of right now in early access, the game is missing some much needed depth. Most MMOs end up looking the same both mechanically and visually over time. The lore also doesn't really get reflected in the world outside of configuration text boxes. If there was more depth in the lore system it would be incredible.

I also wish there was more depth on the class and monster creating mechanics. You can make your traditional warriors and mages well enough, but if you try to make something more clever or different you are kind of stuck.

However, as far as the bones of a game goes, they are very solid foundation. If you go in expecting the game isn't finished, it's a relaxing and cozy time. That being said, I've owned this game for a while. and development has been very slow. It's a small team, so that's not surprising, but really rewarding updates are just so few and far between.

review:
Too bad they didn't make MMORPG Tycoon Tycoon, where you just manage the player playing the game... could have worked out better. 4/10 at current state and price. Come back in a year. Buy it for 5 euro, 10 is a stretch and what it is at... that's called robbery. Wish I could get a refund but spent too much time with hope that it will get better.

You wonder why?
Pros: 

- Cool idea

- Plenty of text based customization (Skills, XP gains, gold, quests, etc)

- Decent amount of characters + Npcs + monsters and they got customization so that is good

- Quite easy to understand and very easy to master (In less than 7 hours I paid off the loan and made more money than I can use.) 

- Fun to look at the little characters to do their thing

- Fun to ban cheaters

- You can take control of an npc and play as them, killing players so that is great

Cons:

- Cool idea but badly executed. Most things just don't stick together or are made poorly

- Not much control over bringing attention of players to specific locations (They will focus on whatever is closet to spawn and farm it forever even if the rest of the map is 1000% cooler and can gain more xp)

- The biom laying system is absolute sh** (You want to place Forrest? Oh well, now you can't see shi**)

- Game gives not much explanation about anything but it is easy enough to figure it out if you are a person that likes to tinker.. Poor tutorial is my summary on this

- Every character slot you filled out is sooo poorly auto generated... You got new monster? Oh well it is a wizard but looks like regular wolf... Just for ease of those that do not want to tinker, please just make them accurate to name but give option to customize.

- Price is a joke for the game

- Optimization should be a key in game like that but it is taking a back seat.

- Tech tree or whatever you wanna call it... 3 perks in 7 hours while sitting on a lot of money... You'll need like 100 hours to get them all

- From what I see, latest updates haven't brought anything to the table.

When I initially bought this game a few months after release I thought it was a great start to a game that could be a whole lot of fun once more content is added.....This is one of those games that never get out of early access.

I BOUGHT THIS GAME IN 2021, and I am astonished in the lack of ANY CONTENT ADDED (How is there still only ONE road you can make and no variations??). Don't buy this game, it was pretty much completed as soon as it was launched in "early access". They've added a handful of new assets for the mechanical and magical city updates, and that seems to be about it. I don't know the size of the team, but the progress is so slow maybe comeback in 2 years when they've added 20 more costumes, a few new buildings, and still no new major updates.

It's really too bad too, I love the concept and if there were more content I could easily see myself having a couple hundred hours with a glowing review, and at that point i'd have no problem supporting the devs further by gifting the game to friends but as of right now, maybe buy it heavily discounted but not at $25.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049293356', 'num_games_owned': 303, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 226, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 226, 'last_played': 1696698981}
review:
Manque encore de contenu, et le développeur n'a pas l'air de faire beaucoup de mises à jour ces derniers temps.
Je l'ai acheté au prix fort mais je pense qu'il faut l'acheter en promo et regarder s'il y a effectivement des mises à jours qui apparaissent.

SInon c'est sympa de créer son propre World of warcraft, et de voir les petits bonhommes évoluer dans le jeu. Cependant le jeu commence déjà à rammer autour des 10000 personnages simultanés, ce qui me parait logique et je ne vois pas trop comment le développeur va faire pour régler ce problème technique qui est pour moi insolvable. À la différence de wow qui n'a qu'à afficher un personnage dans un état et une position donnée avec chaque utilisateur qui s'occupe des calculs, ici c'est votre machine qui fait tourner l'ensemble et donc pour moi le jeu se confronte à une limite infranchissable, hors la façon dont le jeu a été pensé c'est une augmentation permanente et exponentielle du nombre de joueurs et donc de capacité de calculs.
À surveiller.

Je ne le recommande pas pour le moment même si le concept est intéressant car trop de monde ont fait le choix de recommander et donne l'impression que le jeu est exceptionnel à l'heure actuelle.

The AI's all have generated names and some are streamers who could help your game grow. You can also run ad's to gather new players, add props to spice up your towns, add guards to help out those struggling players.

review:
C'est vraiment très satisfaisant de pouvoir faire son propre MMO!

Il vaut vraiment son prix. On peut créer des zones avec des biomes, bâtiments, etc.. On peut créer ses propres classes avec personnalisation de l'apparence, des sorts, des skills, pv, etc. On peut créer des mobs, PNJs, etc. 
Il y a également des aspects de gestion "hors du jeu", comme de l'argent, le recrutement de devs, MJs, la publicité pour le jeu, les commentaires des joueurs, les cheateurs, la note de notre jeu, etc.

Dommage que ce soit une toute petite équipe, du coup les mises à jour sont assez distantes dans le temps, alors qu'on aimerait qu'il y en ait beaucoup plus, quitte à avoir une augmentation du prix du jeu ou même des DLCs pour soutenir les dévs!!!

review:
So far a very good game will be investing a lot more time. The price is worth it even more so if on sale.

Now for what is already in the game I found that the warning button either does not work or i have not unlocked it? I try clicking and holding on a player to no avail. Also i hope we can customize the (boss) mob a bit more so they dont just look like a bigger version of everything else which is a cool base but personally I would like to customize them so they stand out a bit more. I have not looked at dungeons yet the screen shots look good but id like to unlock parties first. I'm also not a fan of the network system but I can see why it was implemented it just took a while to figure out that mob areas also need it and going to a new zone was a bit rough, would've made a better initial placement of the network thing.

Overall a very good game if you give it a chance without trying to limit time played for the refund because it took me about 2 hours to customize my starter area after finishing the tutorial and creating a new game, although a lot of it was figuring things out and flipping through tabs. Looking forward to more content coming to the game.

review:
Hard to thumbs up or down this game.
It's an amazing game idea with tons of potential. Could easily be fixed by mods/community coming together and making stuff.
But there isn't really mod support yet, it lacks a lot of basic mechanics, and every new thing they've released has been a bit bare bones, and only added the amount that needs to be fixed or increased the need for more in depth mechanics. There are a lot of yet to be's that are frequently advertised by the devs and disc for the last two+ years out of the three it's been out for, and they may eventually come out, but haven't seen it yet, and it is said that for example, dungeons was supposed to "coming out soon" more than two years ago, and they've not gotten very far into developing this mechanic considering the time scale - apparently going to be released in multiple releases, so even when it does drop, still not going to be finished like everything else. And the game has become a bit stagnant, as nothing is going to get touched till they release dungeons, so it's become a circle jerk. 
Dev's may be listening to feedback and such, idk cause nothing will ever get done... It's definitely dying/going to die soon if they don't figure out what they are doing as the communities are dwindling more and more as people give up waiting for something that keeps getting promised to be out, "soon", "end of this year", "beginning half of this year", just for nothing to happen over and over. It's quite disheartening. 

Game could be good in a few years if things start getting finished and polished up a tiny bit rather than not. Though I thought this a few years ago, and nothing has changed, so. IDK.

Dev team is too small and not good enough it seems. I've seen single-man run games come out with stuff faster, with more complicated mechanics, and wonderful graphics, while also being far more optimized.

TLDR: Great game, highly unfinished, new mechanics come out highly unfinished and unpollished; and dev's overpromise when things will come out by a few years+, stagnating the content updates as they won't work on anything else.

review:
[i]Just a tiny hot-take before anything: the devs has the worst sense of proportions I ever seem LOL
Now to the actual review...[/i]

My opinion about this game is that it has an inovating and awesome idea, and it's still very rough, bare and bland. It's to be expected from a Early Access, and they got a considerable evolution since 2021, when I bought the game. On that time, we couldn't resize props, scenery were lacking, there was no modular buildings, and combat system was somewhat too simple (it still is, but they got a considerable improvement). They implemented everything I mentioned before that doesn't had, and is about to hit us with [b]dungeons update[/b], with free beta testing available here on Steam.

Overall, if you buy this game, you will find inovating systems and things to explore and have fun with, but you will feel limited on most of things you do. That's not necessarily a bad thing, as long you be vocal about it and share your feedbacks, in my opinion. But being clear about it, [b]NOTHING[/b] that is already implemented is sufficient as a full feature, and I think they will need some time to enhance everything they got. If things get more customizable, they might literally hit gold with this game.

review:
If you love both Tycoon and MMORPG genres, this game is an absolute delight that seamlessly blends the best of both worlds. The recent wave of criticism seems rather confusing, as my experience has been overwhelmingly positive. Admittedly, after a solid 5-6 hours of play, there is a slight hint of repetitiveness setting in. However, let's not forget that maintaining engagement over such a substantial time span is no mean feat, especially in the context of an early access title.

The dev team is readily available and engages on Discord, consistently providing insights into their ongoing efforts. The notion that updates can be conjured with the wave of a wand is far from reality, The beta testing phase for Dungeons update is currently live in the beta branch on steam. The game is in a state of active evolution, which is remarkably evident in the sheer enjoyment it offers.

I have not had any bugs in my gameplay, so I don't know what bugs people are talking about.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988241018', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 965, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 93, 'playtime_at_review': 808, 'last_played': 1712266054}
review:
TLDR:
Le concept est vraiment sympa, les graphismes sont cool mais c'est tout. Le principal problème du jeu est qu'on avance sans but, il n'y a rien à débloquer on a presque tous les éléments dès le début et pas vraiment de challenge. Il y a plein de concepts mais aucun n'est travaillé suffisamment pour apporter un épanouissement... Il y a trop de chose incomplètes et trop de choses inutiles. Il aurait fallu moins de feature mais mieux approfondies. Au final on se retrouve grosso modo avec un éditeur 3D pour modéliser des zones, ce qui pour 20€ est un peu cher. Donc on s'amuse bien les premières heures puis on s'ennuie.

Détails:

Globalement il est assez facile de se faire de l'argent ce qui fait que le côté gestion passe un peu en arrière plan. L'argent ne sert à rien à part agrandir notre MMO plus vite => côté gestion pas terrible

Fonctionnalité "Bande passante": Je ne comprends pas vraiment l'utilité de cette mécanique où il faut relier des zones par des câbles pour fournir du débit. Ce n'est pas franchement intéressant ni compliqué en l'état tant que vous avez des sous => fonctionnalité pas approfondie

Triche des joueurs: les joueurs peuvent tricher et vous pouvez passer un outil sur eux pour détecter les tricheurs et les bans ou leur donner un avertissement. Encore une fois c'est un peu léger comme feature, il faut le faire de temps en temps.

Terrain: Les possibilités de modélisation du terrain sont assez faibles, on peut surtout placer des éléments décoratifs et des bâtiments sur le terrain. => C'est esthétique en early accès donc pourquoi pas.

Les quêtes: Les quêtes sont donnés par des PNJ donneur de quête. Elles se résument en deux actions possibles: aller dans un bâtiment ou aller tuer des monstres et c'est tout. Il n'est pas pas possible de mettre des prérequis même les plus basiques (ex: être niveau X, avoir terminé une autre quête). Pas de gestion de loot non plus. On peut faire des suites de quête mais ca doit rester sur le même pnj ce qui est assez contraignant. => La encore c'est très limité, on aimerait pouvoir faire des quêtes plus fun et plus travaillées

Les chefs de classes: ils sont là pour enseigner les sorts. Ils ne servent à rien d'autre (ils ne peuvent pas donner des quêtes de classe par exemple) => Feature trop légère

Les bâtiments: il y a un nombre très restreint de bâtiment qui fournissent des services pour les joueurs. Ces bâtiments influencent sur l'équilibrage puisque les joueurs vont pouvoir acheter des potions ou des armes. Leur fonctionnement n'est pas explicité, les joueurs achètent des services pour leur aventure avec l'or qu'ils gagnent. C'est difficile d'équilibrer les sorts et les stats des joueurs quand ceux-ci sont sous perfusion de potions.. Autre remarque (esthétique), on ne peut pas préciser le type d'arme que peut équiper une classe donc on peut se retrouver avoir des archers avec des masses qui lancent des projectiles. En plus il faut faire plusieurs auberges car la place est limité. => Là encore il y a des idées mais c'est insuffisant

AI des joueurs est désastreuse. On a un comportement de poisson rouge incohérent. Le joueur débute une quête puis décide d'aller voir un endroit à l'autre bout de la carte sans raison puis décide de se déconnecter. Les joueurs se retrouvent parfois avec beaucoup de quête simultanément et choisissent une action random dans leur liste de truc à faire. Ils aiment bien socialiser dans les zones des monstres car c'est évidemment le meilleur endroit pour papoter. => On pourrait s'attendre à ce que le "coeur" du jeu fonctionne quand même correctement, et bien non ! C'est assez frustrant.

Côté satisfaction des joueurs, la liste des remarques des joueurs ne fait que s'empiler sans jamais diminuer ce qui fait qu'on doit se trimbaler des remarques qui ne sont plus d'actualités toute la partie. => Là encore c'est un jeu de gestion, c'est censé être le coeur du truc (donc fonctionner normalement), et bien non plus !

Le design des classes et des monstres (sorts/stats) est assez simple mais efficace. On peut faire quelques sorts basiques avec des quelques effets. C'est la partie que j'ai bien aimé. Mais c'est quand même assez chaotique à tester car il faut suivre un joueur pour moi les sorts qu'il lance et estimer si c'est assez correct ou non. Si on combine ca avec l'effet poisson rouge on n'a pas l'occasion de beaucoup tester. On a un DPS théorique mais ce n'est pas très représentatif des classes car il y a bien d'autres paramètres à prendre en compte (tankiness, heal, protection, melee/distant) etc. Le jeu donne un rang à nos classes (S, A, B, C, etc..) mais la notation n'est pas transparente et on se demande si c'est vraiment pertinent. Pour exemple j'avais un druide distance qui pouvait kite mais du coup avec un dps réduit et les joueurs demandent un buff (alors que c'était op)
=> C'est la partie la plus fun mais il difficile de tester nos sorts et mécanique. De plus en combat on ne voit pas les buffs des joueurs, leur cd, etc.. Au moins sur le joueur en combat qu'on cible (ou controle) on pourrait avoir ses infos pour voir comment l'IA jouent nos classes. Là encore c'est insuffisant, frustrant et bugué.

On peut espérer que les développeurs travaillent sur ces points mais vu les autres commentaires je pense qu'il ne faut pas trop espérer. Il y avait juste assez pour nous faire jouer plus de 2h et empocher les 20€. J'ai un peu l'impression de m'être fait voler. C'est dommage car le concept était quand même intéressant.

review: This is a fun tycoon game that captures building your own MMORPG well. It has a decent amount to do content wise currently. However, a lot of it does get repetitive after a little while. This is because there isn't a huge amount of variety of scenery items that really help set the scene as well as the quests system seems to be some what limited on what you can setup quest wise. Being either a fetch quest or kill X amount of enemies quest. The depth of the game could be so much more. I know this is in early access but it seems to have been in early access for a very long time with updates being few and far between. I know developing games isn't easy or quick for any game that is of good quality. However, I've played early access games by solo developers that churn out decent sized updates on a regular basis to keep the content of the game expanding and alive and it is received much better that way. For it's current asking price I can't recommend this game for what you get content wise and with how long this game takes to get any meaningful updates. If they do come along though and this game starts to get some more in depth content to really build on what is solid foundations currently then I would recommend this game because it has a lot of potential. Also, if the developer introduced a steam workshop for this game that alone would be huge as then we'd see a whole library full of fan made content to add to the game that would make the experience so much better. I can also confirm this game does also run out the box fine on the steam deck. Once you get a few thousand players in your game though its worth turning some settings down as you'll soon go down to 40fps which is still alright.

author: {'steamid': '76561198096900675', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 15649, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11897, 'last_played': 1709626250}
review:
As I approached the end of my first playthrough, I began to wonder if the AI was a bit bad at navigating the world. I began to think "Are they even TRYING to do some of this content that I made for them?" And then came to notice a player named "Vastbug" who got levels 18 and 19 first. When I tell you that I was OVERJOYED to see his cute ass grind out level 20 by killing mobs instead of questing (true mmo chad), he PURCHASED A TRINKET to celebrate being the first to max level. He then migrated to the endgame boss that I set up just for this occasion! It may seem like a small thing, but this was the cherry on top of fantastic experience of building this world, solving problems, and watching the AI run around playing your game that you set up! I couldn't recommend this game enough to anyone who had a childhood dream of running an MMO. I really like the world that I built, and I'm thinking about uploading it somewhere for people to experience. Yes, it's a sim game where you make a game. The players in your game are not real. There are none of the real complexities that come with actually developing a game. But do you FEEL like you are actually developing a game at times? Absolutely. Fun game.

Also, I know it's early access, but...... Dungeons please ;)

Easy 9/10 if it is your thing, and this is only early access stage

author: {'steamid': '76561198153210112', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 395, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 163, 'last_played': 1685287577}
review:
Начнем с того, что в игре есть куча минусов. Я приведу их кратким списком, поскольку на мой взгляд, они не существенны:

- Деревья не просвечивают и не имеют коллизии, из-за чего человечков в них не видно.
- Слишком "усредненный" набор статов для создания своих скилов а.к.а набор лего "ММО мечты".
- Из моделек в редакторе трудно сделать что-то аутентичное, только "челопиздриков".
- Слишком мало функциональных зданий.
- Слишком мало функционала в функционирующих зданиях. 
- Долгострой.
- Куча фишек которые прое...забыли ввести, либо пока не ввели.

Окей? С минусами разобрались? Отлично! А теперь о том, почему этот кусок анимированных полигонов похожий на дешевую юнити поделку стоит брат:

Когда я наткнулся на эту игру, то первое о чем я подумал, это "Они опять собираются сделать простенький симулятор чего-то. Типа как БатлРоял Тайкун какой-нибудь". Я думал, что в ней ничего не будет, только какая-то система "клиентов" которую нужно постоянно привлекать. А потом я начал натыкаться на всякие приколы в интернете, типа того, что ты реально можешь закастомить способность ЛЮБОМУ персонажу, поставить цену на услугу в каком-нибудь здании, распределить регионы по уровню игроков и регулировать количество получаемого опыта и саму экономику в игре. 

У игры есть огромный потанцевал и я надеюсь, что разработчик введет хотя бы возможность строить данжи. В идеале в игре буквально напрашивается система, по которой человечки-бы сами себе дома строили. Может я еще до этой системы не доиграл, но они у меня селятся только в тавернах. 

В общем, о чем это я? Ах да! Иди покупай. Я порекомендовал.

review:
Dans un premier temps, merci à jdg de m'avoir fait découvrir ce petit bijou qu'est MMORPG Tycoon 2. J'ai pas encore énormément joué (presque 20h au moment du post) mais j'ai adoré, ça faisait très longtemps qu'un jeu ne m'avait pas procuré autant de plaisir. C'est super chill, on peut y jouer en faisant d'autres choses à côté mais c'est tellement bon de créer son petit jeu avec les décors, la méta, les sorts des classes.

J'ai commencé à y jouer en vocal avec un pote, on a créé notre premier mmo en même temps et on s'est bien marré à découvrir la classe des tréants, à regarder nos villes et à se les présenter et vraiment une des meilleures soirées que j'ai vécu en jouant à un jeu. 

Alors je vais pas faire de critique constructive en expliquant les points positifs et les points négatifs. Je voulais juste donner mon ressenti après une vingtaine d'heures passé dessus et j'espère vous avoir donner envie d'y jouer. Mais voilà, si vous voulez un jeu chill, pas prise de tête où vous voulez créer votre petit univers alors foncez et essayez ce jeu.

The concept for this game is the only good thing I can really say about it, execution tho, for the almost past 3 years, is an other story...

And well, I could've make a largely extended review that would explain pretty much everything what's wrong here and there, but besides that I rather won't add anything new what very most of recent negative reviews are already saying about it, I don't think that any of that is even going to change in the near and even further future.

I will keep tracking the updates tho, and if the developers won't die from an old age while working on it, I'm pretty sure that one day, it will be a truly amazing experience to have fun with.

But for now, I just can't feel anything else than just being greatly disappointed.
(as the game changes for the better while full release, I'll surely change my review as well)

As it stands for now, I do not recommend it to anyone.

review: MMORPG Tycoon 2 ist ein unterhaltsames und entspanntes Spiel für alle, die ein relativ einfaches Management und Aufbauspiel mögen. In MMORPG Tycoon 2 baut ihr anhand einer Vielzahl von Objekten euer eigens MMO auf. Ihr könnt eigene Klassen und Gegner im Designer entwerfen und sogar deren Fähigkeiten nach belieben gestallten. Wenn ihr kreativ seid dann sind euch kaum Grenzen gesetzt, was eure Spielwelt, Klassen und Gegner betrifft. Das Management ist recht unkompliziert gehalten. Ihr stellt Personal ein, wie Entwickler und Gamemaster, die sich dann um Bugs und andere Probleme kümmern. Ansonsten verwaltet ihr die Preise im Spiel, beispielsweise vom Waffenhändler, den Tavernen etc. Das Spiel ist somit auch für junges Publikum geeignet. Kreativität und Fantasie solltet ihr allerdings schon mitbringen, da euch ansonsten recht schnell die Lust am Spiel vergehen kann. Da man, außer einer Spielwelt aufzubauen, nicht wirklich viel anderes zu tun hat.  Das Spiel läuft sehr gut und mir sind in meinen fast 50 Stunden Spielzeit keine Bugs aufgefallen. Negativ wäre an dieser Stelle noch anzumerken, dass die eigentlichen Updates "lange" auf sich warten lassen. Daher ist davon auszugehen, dass dieses Spiel noch sehr lange im Early Access sein wird. Ihr solltet daher überlegen ob ihr soviel Geduld mitbringen könnt oder lieber mit dem Kauf warten wollt.
